abstract: Start of federal trial in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, is aimed at determining whether recent changes in North Carolina's election laws, implemented after Voting Rights Act of 1965 was struck down in 2013, discriminate against black voters; case may have wide repercussions, helping to pinpoint scope of voting rights protections nationwide in 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A federal trial is meant to determine whether recent changes in the state’s election laws discriminate against black voters. It could help define the scope of voting rights across the country in the coming presidential election.

headline.main: Voting Rights Legacy of the ’60s Heads to Court as North Carolina Law Is Tested
headline.print_headline: A Voting Rights Legacy of 1960s Heads to Court

snippet: A federal trial is meant to determine whether recent changes in the state’s election laws discriminate against black voters. It could help define the scope of voting rights across the country in the coming presidential election.
